elements.content: Fig. 2 Crystal packing views of 1 under N2O atmosphere at 293 K (a) and at 93 K (b) with a stick model. The C2/c crystal (a) has a channel structure with a narrow neck of ca. 2 Å diameter. The P 1 ̄ crystal (b) generated in including N2O molecular wires in its channels.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="simple-para0035" view="all">A novel inclusion crystal, {[Rh(II)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bza)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(pyz)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)} (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), was prepared and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis; linear alignment (N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> coherently generates in the channels of host rhodium benzoate pyrazine and there is a high possibility of the existence of an intermediate phase induced by a slight amount of adsorbed N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O inside the crystal even at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel inclusion crystal, {[Rh(II)2(bza)4(pyz)] n  ⋅3n(N2O)} (1), was prepared and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis; linear alignment (N2O) n  coherently generates in the channels of host rhodium benzoate pyrazine and there is a high possibility of the existence of an intermediate phase induced by a slight amount of adsorbed N2O inside the crystal even at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0005" view="all">Dinuclear metal carboxylates, M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CR)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, represent an important class of transition metal complexes with respect to the study of structure and metal–metal interaction . Several chain compounds of dinuclear metal carboxylates have been isolated in order to produce new types of chain compounds . Interestingly, some of them show gas-adsorption properties, presenting a new aspect of chain complexes, which is constructed by the van der Waals interactions among chain building blocks . The gas-adsorption properties of [Rh<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bza)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(pyz)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (bza and pyz=benzoate and pyrazine) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) have been investigated . More recently, thermal analyses of the copper isomer of crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has revealed phase transition induced by CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas adsorption  and single crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> transforms to a CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> inclusion crystal, accompanied by the reversible appearance and disappearance of channels in the crystal structure through gas adsorption . Although the crystal transformation from empty crystal to CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> inclusion crystal was determined, the effects for crystal transformation by fluid adsorbed gas diffusing inside the crystal has not yet been elucidated. We focus on nitrous oxide (N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O), which has an isoelectronic and isosteric linear trinuclear structure (N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O) with CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and strong intermolecular interaction, which influences the inclusion formation due to its large dipole moment. From the perspective of the regulation of specific processes of live organisms, the N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O inclusion crystal is very interesting. This is because N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O is used as an anesthetic (“laughing gas”) and the generation of anesthesia is considered to be caused by the ability of albumen molecules to form clathrate-like hydrate structures, which become stabilized at the temperature of the human body . Here, we report on the preparation of an inclusion single crystal with coherent alignment of included N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and strong evidence for crystal transformation induced by the diffusing adsorbed N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gas.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Dinuclear metal carboxylates, M2(O2CR)4, represent an important class of transition metal complexes with respect to the study of structure and metal-metal interaction . Several chain compounds of dinuclear metal carboxylates have been isolated in order to produce new types of chain compounds . Interestingly, some of them show gas-adsorption properties, presenting a new aspect of chain complexes, which is constructed by the van der Waals interactions among chain building blocks . The gas-adsorption properties of [Rh2(bza)4(pyz)] n  (bza and pyz=benzoate and pyrazine) (1) have been investigated . More recently, thermal analyses of the copper isomer of crystal 1 has revealed phase transition induced by CO2 gas adsorption  and single crystal 1 transforms to a CO2 inclusion crystal, accompanied by the reversible appearance and disappearance of channels in the crystal structure through gas adsorption . Although the crystal transformation from empty crystal to CO2 inclusion crystal was determined, the effects for crystal transformation by fluid adsorbed gas diffusing inside the crystal has not yet been elucidated. We focus on nitrous oxide (N2O), which has an isoelectronic and isosteric linear trinuclear structure (NNO) with CO2 and strong intermolecular interaction, which influences the inclusion formation due to its large dipole moment. From the perspective of the regulation of specific processes of live organisms, the N2O inclusion crystal is very interesting. This is because N2O is used as an anesthetic ("laughing gas") and the generation of anesthesia is considered to be caused by the ability of albumen molecules to form clathrate-like hydrate structures, which become stabilized at the temperature of the human body . Here, we report on the preparation of an inclusion single crystal with coherent alignment of included N2O and strong evidence for crystal transformation induced by the diffusing adsorbed N2O gas.

elements.content: Single-crystal analyses under a N2O gas atmosphere revealed the crystal transformation of 1 from monoclinic to triclinic crystal systems. As the crystal was cooled in a N2O atmosphere, the crystal structure in the monoclinic space group C2/c at 293 K underwent a phase transition to a new structure adopting the triclinic space group P 1 ̄ , obviously generating one-dimensional channels including N2O molecules. The N2O inclusion crystal was also determined at 175 K with the P 1 ̄ space group, suggesting that the crystal transformation occurs between 293 and 175 K. The ORTEP views and packing views of host 1 under N2O at 293 K and those including N2O at 93 K are shown in . The chain skeleton was maintained in both cases. Adsorbed N2O molecules are fitted into the channels in a linear arrangement along the b axis of the P 1 ̄ crystal cell. The crystallographic data is summarized in .
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal analyses under a N2O gas atmosphere  revealed the crystal transformation of 1 from monoclinic to triclinic crystal systems. As the crystal was cooled in a N2O atmosphere, the crystal structure in the monoclinic space group C2/c at 293 K underwent a phase transition to a new structure adopting the triclinic space group P 1 ̄  , obviously generating one-dimensional channels including N2O molecules. The N2O inclusion crystal was also determined at 175 K with the P 1 ̄   space group, suggesting that the crystal transformation occurs between 293 and 175 K. The ORTEP views and packing views of host 1 under N2O at 293 K and those including N2O at 93 K are shown in   . The chain skeleton was maintained in both cases. Adsorbed N2O molecules are fitted into the channels in a linear arrangement along the b axis of the P 1 ̄   crystal cell. The crystallographic data is summarized in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0015" view="all">The geometry of included N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules at 93 K is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules are arranged in linear fashion along the one-dimensional channels in the form of molecular wires that are separated by a distance of <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 1 nm. The molecular axes of the N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules are almost parallel and perpendicular to the channel direction at sites A and B, respectively, with the A–B–B linkage having an angle of 124.8° at the central N atom. Crystallography cannot distinguish between nitrogen (N(3)) and oxygen (O(5)) atoms on the terminal positions of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at site A due to their symmetrical positions relative to the central N(2) atom. The N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O and N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N atomic distances between neighboring N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules are very short, ranging from 2.87 to 3.54 Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The geometry of included N2O molecules at 93 K is shown in  . The N2O molecules are arranged in linear fashion along the one-dimensional channels in the form of molecular wires that are separated by a distance of ca. 1 nm. The molecular axes of the N2O molecules are almost parallel and perpendicular to the channel direction at sites A and B, respectively, with the A-B-B linkage having an angle of 124.8° at the central N atom. Crystallography cannot distinguish between nitrogen (N(3)) and oxygen (O(5)) atoms on the terminal positions of N2O at site A due to their symmetrical positions relative to the central N(2) atom. The NO and NN atomic distances between neighboring N2O molecules are very short, ranging from 2.87 to 3.54 Å.

elements.content: The crystal structure of the N2O inclusion crystal described here is similar to that of 1 including CO2 at 93 K , dominantly due to the same trinuclear molecules with the linear geometry of N2O as observed for that of the included CO2. In the case of 1 under CO2, the probability of the crystal transformation of 1 under CO2 gas at 293 K was indicated even by the diffusing adsorbent gas molecules inside the crystal, but the crystal phase does not change and maintains the C2/m space group, which is almost the same crystal data of 1 measured in an inert oil, and finally transforms to the P 1 ̄ space group to generate inclusion crystals as the temperature decreases . Unlike the case of 1 under CO2 gas, crystal 1 displays the C2/c space group under a N2O atmosphere at 293 K . The C2/c crystal has a channel structure with a narrow neck of ca. 2 Å diameter. This result demonstrates the intermediate phase between the empty host with C2/m and the inclusion solid with P 1 ̄ under N2O condition. Thus the two-step phase transition of 1 happens under the N2O condition. This strongly indicates that the crystal transformation from C2/m to C2/c crystals is caused by a slight amount of adsorbed N2O molecules inside the crystals, which should still have a fluid nature in the narrow channel.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of the N2O inclusion crystal described here is similar to that of 1 including CO2 at 93 K , dominantly due to the same trinuclear molecules with the linear geometry of N2O as observed for that of the included CO2. In the case of 1 under CO2, the probability of the crystal transformation of 1 under CO2 gas at 293 K was indicated even by the diffusing adsorbent gas molecules inside the crystal, but the crystal phase does not change and maintains the C2/m space group, which is almost the same crystal data of 1 measured in an inert oil, and finally transforms to the P 1 ̄   space group to generate inclusion crystals as the temperature decreases . Unlike the case of 1 under CO2 gas, crystal 1 displays the C2/c space group under a N2O atmosphere at 293 K . The C2/c crystal has a channel structure with a narrow neck of ca. 2 Å diameter. This result demonstrates the intermediate phase between the empty host with C2/m and the inclusion solid with P 1 ̄   under N2O condition. Thus the two-step phase transition of 1 happens under the N2O condition. This strongly indicates that the crystal transformation from C2/m to C2/c crystals is caused by a slight amount of adsorbed N2O molecules inside the crystals, which should still have a fluid nature in the narrow channel.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="para0025" view="all">The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O adsorption isotherm curves on <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 293 and 195 K are depicted together in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>
. The isotherm is gradually reached for the adsorption amounts of 26.5 and 106.9 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>(STP)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 293 and 195 K under 800 Torr, respectively, with accompanying hysteresis loops. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were at 0.91 and 3.68 N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per Rh<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit at 293 and 195 K, respectively. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> seem slightly large in comparison with that observed in the crystallography (3.0 N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O per Rh<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> below 175 K). This might be caused by the deviation of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gas from the ideal gas property. Crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, however, adsorbs the certain quantity of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O even at 293 K, which should be adsorbed through the narrow voids of crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as shown in . The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules inside the crystal at 293 K, which could not be located by single crystal X-ray analysis, cause crystal transformation from <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>/m</ce:italic> to <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic> crystals during N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O adsorption at approximately room temperature. Considering the very similar structure of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, the remarkable difference in the nature of these molecules is the strong intermolecular interaction ability of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O due to the highly polarized N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>
<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> structure, which may cause the intermediate phase at 293 K.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The N2O adsorption isotherm curves on 1 at 293 and 195 K are depicted together in   . The isotherm is gradually reached for the adsorption amounts of 26.5 and 106.9 cm3(STP)g-1 at 293 and 195 K under 800 Torr, respectively, with accompanying hysteresis loops. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N2O were at 0.91 and 3.68 N2O molecules per Rh2 unit at 293 and 195 K, respectively. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N2O in crystal 1 seem slightly large in comparison with that observed in the crystallography (3.0 N2O per Rh2 below 175 K). This might be caused by the deviation of N2O gas from the ideal gas property. Crystal 1, however, adsorbs the certain quantity of N2O even at 293 K, which should be adsorbed through the narrow voids of crystal 1 as shown in . The N2O molecules inside the crystal at 293 K, which could not be located by single crystal X-ray analysis, cause crystal transformation from C2/m to C2/c crystals during N2O adsorption at approximately room temperature. Considering the very similar structure of N2O and CO2, the remarkable difference in the nature of these molecules is the strong intermolecular interaction ability of N2O due to the highly polarized NN+ O- structure, which may cause the intermediate phase at 293 K.

elements.content: <ce:para id="para0030" view="all">In conclusion, N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O guest molecules transform crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> even by slight amounts of adsorbed N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gas through an intermediate phase, which includes diffusing guest molecules inside the crystal, finally reaching an inclusion crystal with coherently aligned N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules. The intermediate phase is most likely stabilized by the strong intermolecular interactions among the guest molecules, and the final inclusion crystal structure might be determined by the geometry and structure of the guest and host solids.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, N2O guest molecules transform crystal 1 even by slight amounts of adsorbed N2O gas through an intermediate phase, which includes diffusing guest molecules inside the crystal, finally reaching an inclusion crystal with coherently aligned N2O molecules. The intermediate phase is most likely stabilized by the strong intermolecular interactions among the guest molecules, and the final inclusion crystal structure might be determined by the geometry and structure of the guest and host solids.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para id="simple-para0040" view="all">
<ce:italic>Preparation of the inclusion crystal</ce:italic>: The single crystal host of rhodium(II) benzoate pyrazine [Rh(II)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bza)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(pyz)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was prepared as . A well-formed single crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> of red platelet with 0.15<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.02 mm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> was sealed inside of sodalite capillary with 0.5 mm diameter (W. Müller Co. Ltd.) in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O atmosphere. The capillary was mounted on a goniometer head of an X-ray diffractometer at room temperature, then gently cooled in a cold nitrogen flow to target temperatures at a decreasing rate of <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 1 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The inclusion formation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. <ce:italic>Crystallographic analyses</ce:italic>: The data for all structures was measured on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073 Å) at 293, 175, and 93 K. An empirical absorption correction (ABSCOR) was applied. The structure was solved using the Patterson method (DIRDIF94 PATTY) and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by the full-matrix least squares (SHELXL97) method using a teXsan software package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, hydrogens were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as

<ce:e-component id="MMC1">

</ce:alt-e-component>
</ce:e-component>
</display> Nos. CCDC – 208,442 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at 293 K), 208,443 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) at 175 K), 208,444 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>3(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) at 93 K). Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk)</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Preparation of the inclusion crystal: The single crystal host of rhodium(II) benzoate pyrazine [Rh(II)2(bza)4(pyz)] n  (1) was prepared as . A well-formed single crystal 1 of red platelet with 0.15×0.10×0.02 mm3 was sealed inside of sodalite capillary with 0.5 mm diameter (W. Müller Co. Ltd.) in N2O atmosphere. The capillary was mounted on a goniometer head of an X-ray diffractometer at room temperature, then gently cooled in a cold nitrogen flow to target temperatures at a decreasing rate of ca. 1 °C min-1. The inclusion formation of 1 ⋅3(N2O) was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. Crystallographic analyses: The data for all structures was measured on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ=0.71073 Å) at 293, 175, and 93 K. An empirical absorption correction (ABSCOR) was applied. The structure was solved using the Patterson method (DIRDIF94 PATTY) and refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least squares (SHELXL97) method using a teXsan software package. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, hydrogens were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as    Background data text    Background data text     Nos. CCDC - 208,442 (1 in N2O at 293 K), 208,443 (1 ⋅3(N2O) at 175 K), 208,444 (1 ⋅3(N2O) at 93 K). Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: (+44) 1223-336-033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk)

elements.content: Crystallographic analyses of 1 under CO2 atmosphere show the crystals in the monoclinic space group C2/m at 293 K: in inert oil (a, b, c=17.821(9), 9.605(5), 12.362(8) Å, β=127.53(4), V=1678(1) Å3, Z=2); in CO2 gas (a, b, c=17.85(1), 9.465(5), 14.113(9) Å, β=137.20(2), V=1620(1) Å3, Z=2), and then crystal 1 transforms to P 1 ̄ inclusion crystal at 93 K (a, b, c=9.556(3), 10.318(4), 11.079(5) Å, α, β, γ=70.18(3), 66.12(3), 63.02(3)°, V=873.7(6) Å3, Z=1). These results are described in

elements.clean_text:
The observed C2/c crystal under N2O condition described in this paper is very similar to that in inert oil at 93 K (a, b, c=17.42(3), 9.55(1), 19.70(4) Å, β=98.05(6)°, V=3244(9) Å3, Z=4) in  

Adsorption isotherm curves were measured by a volumeric method on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 at 215 K (dry ice in ethanol bath) and 293 K (water bath) in the pressure range from 0.1 to 800 Torr

cln_elements.content: The N2O adsorption isotherm curves on 1 at 293 and 195 K are depicted together in . The isotherm is gradually reached for the adsorption amounts of 26.5 and 106.9 cm3(STP)g−1 at 293 and 195 K under 800 Torr, respectively, with accompanying hysteresis loops. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N2O were at 0.91 and 3.68 N2O molecules per Rh2 unit at 293 and 195 K, respectively. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N2O in crystal 1 seem slightly large in comparison with that observed in the crystallography (3.0 N2O per Rh2 below 175 K). This might be caused by the deviation of N2O gas from the ideal gas property. Crystal 1, however, adsorbs the certain quantity of N2O even at 293 K, which should be adsorbed through the narrow voids of crystal 1 as shown in . The N2O molecules inside the crystal at 293 K, which could not be located by single crystal X-ray analysis, cause crystal transformation from C2/m to C2/c crystals during N2O adsorption at approximately room temperature. Considering the very similar structure of N2O and CO2, the remarkable difference in the nature of these molecules is the strong intermolecular interaction ability of N2O due to the highly polarized NN+ O− structure, which may cause the intermediate phase at 293 K.Crystallographic analyses of 1 under CO2 atmosphere show the crystals in the monoclinic space group C2/m at 293 K: in inert oil (a, b, c=17.821(9), 9.605(5), 12.362(8) Å, β=127.53(4), V=1678(1) Å3, Z=2); in CO2 gas (a, b, c=17.85(1), 9.465(5), 14.113(9) Å, β=137.20(2), V=1620(1) Å3, Z=2), and then crystal 1 transforms to P 1 ̄ inclusion crystal at 93 K (a, b, c=9.556(3), 10.318(4), 11.079(5) Å, α, β, γ=70.18(3), 66.12(3), 63.02(3)°, V=873.7(6) Å3, Z=1). These results are described in
cln_elements.clean_text:
The N2O adsorption isotherm curves on 1 at 293 and 195 K are depicted together in   . The isotherm is gradually reached for the adsorption amounts of 26.5 and 106.9 cm3(STP)g-1 at 293 and 195 K under 800 Torr, respectively, with accompanying hysteresis loops. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N2O were at 0.91 and 3.68 N2O molecules per Rh2 unit at 293 and 195 K, respectively. The estimated adsorbed amounts of N2O in crystal 1 seem slightly large in comparison with that observed in the crystallography (3.0 N2O per Rh2 below 175 K). This might be caused by the deviation of N2O gas from the ideal gas property. Crystal 1, however, adsorbs the certain quantity of N2O even at 293 K, which should be adsorbed through the narrow voids of crystal 1 as shown in . The N2O molecules inside the crystal at 293 K, which could not be located by single crystal X-ray analysis, cause crystal transformation from C2/m to C2/c crystals during N2O adsorption at approximately room temperature. Considering the very similar structure of N2O and CO2, the remarkable difference in the nature of these molecules is the strong intermolecular interaction ability of N2O due to the highly polarized NN+ O- structure, which may cause the intermediate phase at 293 K.

Crystallographic analyses of 1 under CO2 atmosphere show the crystals in the monoclinic space group C2/m at 293 K: in inert oil (a, b, c=17.821(9), 9.605(5), 12.362(8) Å, β=127.53(4), V=1678(1) Å3, Z=2); in CO2 gas (a, b, c=17.85(1), 9.465(5), 14.113(9) Å, β=137.20(2), V=1620(1) Å3, Z=2), and then crystal 1 transforms to P 1 ̄   inclusion crystal at 93 K (a, b, c=9.556(3), 10.318(4), 11.079(5) Å, α, β, γ=70.18(3), 66.12(3), 63.02(3)°, V=873.7(6) Å3, Z=1). These results are described in

crystal system.condition: during N2O adsorption at approximately room temperature

cln_elements.content: Fig. 2 Crystal packing views of 1 under N2O atmosphere at 293 K (a) and at 93 K (b) with a stick model. The C2/c crystal (a) has a channel structure with a narrow neck of ca. 2 Å diameter. The P 1 ̄ crystal (b) generated in including N2O molecular wires in its channels.
